title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Excellent sound, less than declared battery life
author: SWU
content: Just got this Tozo HT2 for three days and continuously tested its sound quality and battery. I will say that its sound quality via Bluetooth is excellent, although a little less so than the Bose QuietComfort I also have, which, of course, is much more expensive. When connected with the 3.5 mm cable, however, its power automatically turns off, hence no more ANC function, but the wired sound quality is still good enough. Tozo's battery life, however, surprisingly falls far short of the 40 hrs with ANC on as the company claims. I charged it in full and tested it several times after each full charge, and the battery life dropped to 90% after one and a half hours of watching a YouTube movie. So by calculation, its battery should be depleted in 15 hours. Bose QuietComfort, on the other hand, claims to have 24 hours of battery life. I have used it intermittently for an hour and its battery life still remained 100%. Bose's battery quality is apparently better than Tozo's. I give Tozo 4 stars for this reason. One mystery is how Tozo will fare on an airplane when it must be connected to the seat's TV screen by cable. Will there be noise cancellation when its power is turned off? Doesn't seem technically possible.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Impressive for 40 bucks
author: S. Abney
content: I always like playing with headphones. My Skullcandy's broke. The power button when straight into the headphones and they were only 2 years old. Did I like them yes, worth the money, no if you compare the ANC 2 abilities. I purchased a pair of Sony WH-1000XM4, they are nice, that app works well. Overall sound quality and adjustments, good. Volume level, pretty good, not going to blast your ears too much which can cause damage, but overall, good sound. So, let's bring in the Tozo HT2. You ask why buy these because you have the Sony, they are almost a $300 pair of headphones? The Sony app only allows connectivity to two devices even if I don't have them not connected to my iPad or my iPhone, they will not sync to the MAC. Stupid Huh? That is a Sony app issue because the way the work, bluetooth to the phone/iPad and then sync'd to the Sony app. It's s double sync, I thought so too. Bluetooth wouldn't even pick them up on the MAC because of it. Here comes in the Tozo. I wanted an in expensive pair to work with my MAC for work meetings. I installed the app on my iPhone and my MAC so I could have EQ. iPhone, the app works just fine. MAC, doesn't see the headphones so I can EQ them, but is picked up via Bluetooth, so I can use them on the MAC. Not really a huge issue since it's just used for Voice. Sound quality is good. the ANC isn't as good as the Sony but not that far off to be honest, but I will say this....the sound quality of the Tozo up against the Sony, you can't tell a difference that much and the volume level on the Tozo is a little more than the Sony. EQ these things out just like the Sony and you wouldn't be able to tell the big of a difference in quality of sound. Sony is just a little crisper, but I bet if I keep tweaking the EQ, it would go away. Most people wouldn't even notice to be honest. Wish I would have found these before the Sony. I would just have bought two pairs in two colors. One for work, one for personal use. So, let's talk about comfort compared ,, the Tozo are more comfortable to me because of the earpieces. Put the Tozo side by side to the Sony and the look almost identical. I've had the Sony for a hot minute so I cannot return them or I would and just go buy another pair of these. For $40 very surprised. It just goes to show you, that if you have an app and the product is good in itself, some of these products do compare to a $300 pair for way less. Give these a shot.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Absolutely INCREDIBLE Headphones - and I'm an audio producer
author: My Humble Opinion
content: My daughter picked these out to use for a trip. I have a pair of Tozo NC'ing earbuds and they were great sounding, just poor fitting. So based on that, we pulled the trigger on these.She got tired of me saying "wow - I'm gonna need to buy a pair of these!" They sound incredible for a sub $50 pair of headphones. Great bass response, nice highs... mids are a little dropped for that "hi-fi" playback sound, but no matter. You can hear everything and it's a pleasant listening experience which is the most important.Noise cancelling is also fantastic. I test the noise cancelling with a white/brown noise machine (usually takes up a lot of the available frequencies) and it removed a lot. In real world situations, it's exactly what you'd want.If you're on the fence, don't hesitate to give these a shot. I've been an audio professional for over 20 years and am very particular about what I like/don't like. I LIKE THESE!

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Learning Curve
author: Taylor
content: I bought these after my beats broke. I only intended to use these for a couple of months until I could afford new beats or the Sony headphones but they work pretty well. It's a bit hard to understand the functions and I spent the first 2 or 3 months believing that there wasn’t a skip track button and was annoyed everytime I would have to open my phone to skip the track, but you just have to long press the volume key to skip or go back. I wouldn't recommend getting these headphones to workout, because when you sweat they easily fall off, so I just use my earbuds. The app is ok. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Surprisingly good all around with just a few cons
author: Amazon Customer
content: This 50.00/under set can hang with most 100.00+ noise cancelling sets. You'd have to go up to 200.00+ headsets to experience significant changes in quality. They very comfy, and i use them all the time around the apartment for late night when listening to podcasts, music, and even movies. timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 18, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great performance for fair price
author: BRYON SCOTT
content: Disclaimer: TOZO gifted these headphones to me. Even so, the following comments are without bias.Build: The phones appear to be well built. The headband adjusts with a clicks that feel solid yet unforced. They sport a sleek and clean look.Comfortability: My previous set of headphones were Logitech H600s. Compared to those, the TOZO unit is larger and heavier. However, the fit is much better and the larger earpads make for a vastly superior feel. I have a smaller head, and the phones fit snuggly, which I like. I'm not sure how comfortable they would be on a larger dome.Sound quality: I am not an audiophile, but I do enjoy good sound quality. If there is anything that bugs me, it's tinny sound. These phone do not suffer from that malady. The bass is warm and solid and the highs are crystal. The sound is several factors better than the H600 headset. In this area, these phones far outperformed my expectations.Microphone: The phones have a built-in microphone that is adequate for communication, but not for professional recording. Audio from the mic sounds a bit like you're in a cave. To be honest, not much can be expected from a mic in any headphone, however.Latency: There is absolutely no noticeable latency in these phones. I am beyond impressed.Noise Canceling / App: I was completely surprised when I discovered the TOZO app and linked them up to the phones. The app provides six noise-canceling modes that work beautifully. I have dogs that bark from time to time and I can clearly tell when their racket is being canceled out. Change the mode and ambient sound is mixed in with my content. Further, once the device is added to the app, you can change modes even when the phones are paired to a different device. Simply brilliant.Other notes: I have not used the headphones long enough to drain the battery yet, so I have no real data on how long a single charge lasts. I have listened for over four hours, however, and had more than 50% charge left at that point. Also, I have only had these for a little more than a week. Sometimes the performance and durability of electronic devices degrades over time. I plan to update the review after several months of use.Overall value: The purchase price of $39 is right in the range of similar headphones on Amazon. That being said, I do not know how they line up to the competition in quality. It's hard to imagine better performance at this price range, however. I am quite satisfied with them.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Very impressed
author: Estella
content: Bought these because my $300 Sony headphones just broke. title: 5.0 out of 5 stars ✈️🎧
author: obk
content: I travel a lot, and always bring a pair of ANC headphones on a plane with me. I went through a number of those already, because they take a lot of abuse over time. My last pair is already aging, so I couldn't pass this deal from TOZO.Pros out of the box+ Obviously, the price+ Metal hoop, folding design, good for compact storage+ large over the ears cups, completely cover my medium size ears. The foam is not as soft as on my other headphones, but very comfortable. I wore those for 3h straight so far, sleeping on a plane -- no issues, no soreness+ ANC works very decently. These things went a long way since a few years ago, so it seems even less expensive models perform quite nice these days.+ Supported by the TOZO app, and I had two firmware update since I bought it. Nice to know the vendor cares about their products.Cons sre my personal:- Seems like an incomplete kit. This product is clearly designed for travel but it comes without a travel case and no two-prong adapter is included, which are still needed on some airlines. Probably too much to ask for the price, but would be a nice touch. Luckily, I had a spare adapter to use, and a generic case from Amazon fits the HT2 just right.- controls are far from perfect: all the buttons have the same profile, without any distinct features and it's difficult to tell which one is which, often confusing NC button with play/pause and other button- NC mode requires turning on the headphones and pairing. You cannot simply use them for noise isolation. My other headphones have a simple hardware toggle switch to quickly turn on and off. Also NC button always cycles through thee modes, and I find the "transparent mode" to be unnecessary.- voice announcements are in English but with thick asian accent. Comprehensive, but surprising in 2023...None of these issues being critical, this product is still a very good deal for the price, so I'm keeping it.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States December 28, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great sound, comfortable, so-so ANC
author: Jerry Hoffmeister
content: My initial impression when I put these on was that the ear cups were a bit small for my ears and they sounded good but the base was a bit punchy / pronounced. After wearing them for awhile, I decided that although my ears touched the sides they cups are quite cushy and surprisingly comfortable. I can wear these for hours without discomfort. I also decided that I liked the sound and wore them for several hours enjoying music and listening to a podcast that day.I'm going to compare the sound and ANC quality to several other headphones / earbuds that I own - Bose QC II earbuds, TOZO Golden X1 earbuds and Sennheiser Momentum 3 headphones.I had no problem getting them paired to my phone and connected in the TOZO app. On first connection to the app, it found a firmware update and that got installed with out issue. This is what I expect but there are other products (notably the Bose QC IIs) that bluetooth and app connections can be an issue.The controls are intuitive and easy to use. I've found this to be true with all of the TOZO products that I've tried.Sound quality: I like listening to them. The highs are crips and the base is punchy with out being muddy. I notice that compared to my Sennheiser's especially, the HT2s sound a but closed in - the Sennheiser's and the Bose both feel more expansive - have a wider soundstage. The HT2s have a wider soundstage than the Golden X1s tho. This is kinda expected tho - both the QC II and the Momentum 3's cost 5-6 times more than the HT2s. Excellent sound for the price.ANC: I found the HT2's ANC to be just OK. They perform similarly to my Momentum 3's. I tested using fan noise - a bathroom fan as well as a speaker playing music. The QC IIs are the gold standard here - they almost completely blocked out the fan noise as well as the music. The Momentum 3s and the HT2s blocked maybe 1/2 of the fan noise. I noticed that they both blocked almost all of the lower frequency fan noise but let thru the higher frequencies. The performance using music was similar - again lower frequencies were attenuated more than high ones. The Golden X1s ANC was marginally worse in both categories although similar. Bose generally wins this contest.Pass thru mode: Again the Bose performed the best but I was quite happy with the pass thru mode for the HT2s. I could easily carry on a conversation in pass thru mode without taking them off of my head.Similar to music, the HT2s were very similar to the Momentum 3's and slightly better than the Golden X1s.Bottom line - these are definitely worth the asking price. Good sound, comfortable, OK ANC and good pass thru mode.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States February 4, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good sound, a little uncomfortable with glasses
author: Joseph
content: I have used other Tozo earphones in the past which were quite good, and these did not disappoint. I'm not an audiophile, and these will probably not compare to $500 dollar headphones, but they do sound good.The noise isolation (passive blocking of sound just from wearing the headphones) is good, and paired with the active noise cancellation it is sufficient for blocking out constant noise such as when in a car. It has a "pass through" mode which allows you to hear things going on around you, which can be a very useful feature, especially when you need to be able to hear your surroundings for safety reasons. It is a little louder than I would like, but I have sensitive ears.Battery life is good, though I couldn't say exactly how long it will last, because I have not had it run out. The box says 56 hours of play time, and I have no reason to doubt that. (That is probably with noise canceling turned off, but even with noise canceling you should be okay for a long day of listening.)I would like it to be lighter weight, but that is the trade off for long battery life and solid construction.I have them paired with both my tablet and my phone, so when I power them on they connect to both, which is convenient for me. Whichever device I push play on will control the headphones, and I don't have to turn off Bluetooth on one device to get them connected to the other as I have needed to with other wireless headphones.The only real problem I have faced is that the earpieces grip my head quite firmly. That is only a problem because of the earpieces on my glasses, which become uncomfortable after a couple hours of being pressed firmly into my head. My head is on the larger side of average, which doesn't help. Without my glasses it is not a problem, so if you don't wear glasses, have a smaller head, or a shorter use session, that shouldn't be a problem for you.All in all I am quite happy with these headphones. As far as I can tell everything is as advertised, and the (advertised) 40mm drivers sound quite good to my ears.

content: I have considerable experience in audio production. I'm taking a long plane trip and wanted to kill the engine noise. These seemed like a good budget option. If you’re an audiophile you won't be disappointed, but you also won't be blown away. You get what you pay for, so you’re not going to get the sound quality you'd get from 400$ bose headphones. I'm not an audiophile, and I was very happy with the sound. The sound could be a little clearer, but it's significantly better than the 60$ headphones I bought before these. I would say the base is average, but with the app you can get a little more base from them if you want. Overall I'd give these 4 stars out of 5 for sound.Second is the noise cancelling/ transparent mode. The noise cancelling isnt the strongest ive tried, but for the price i was very happy. With volume at half I can't hear anything around me, unless someone is screaming or there is a very loud noise close by, and even then its very quiet. When the volume is 25% I can hear some talking, but thats with me trying to hear things. Noise cancelling with no volume isn't about what you'd expect. You can hear talking, or car noises. It's significantly quieter though. Transparent mode, or pass through mode is nice. You can clearly hear things when it's on unless your blasting music. I don't have alot to say about it because I don't use it very often, but it's nice to have when I need it. For the price I'd give these a 5 out 5 stars for this section.Lastly is build quality/ packaging.I was very surprised when I got the box. It's very sleek, and clean. It almost feels like your opening somthing from Apple. I was even more surprised when I opened the box and held the headphones. The build quality is great , and Id honestly compare these to the quality of bose. They feel very nice, and sturdy. It's not light like some 20 dollar ones you'd get, but also not heavy or cumbersome when you wear them for a while. The ear muffs are very soft and comfortable. I could easily wear them for a several hours with no discomfort. As a plus they also come with a charger, and an aux cord if you need it. I'd easily give these a 5 out of 5 stars for this section.Just as a side note, the battery life is better than you'd ever need. The company says you can get uo to 60 hours of battery life from them. I cant say for sure, but Ive had them for 2 days, and using them all day i still have 60% battery left. You really can't go wrong buying from this company. The customer service is very very good. They go above and beyond to make sure you’re happy. One of my tozo nc7s earbuds stopped working within warranty and the company replaced it. So far I've been very happy with every product I've tried from them.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars A utilitarian device for a decent price.
author: Justchillin
content: It comes packed in a nice sturdy box. No carry case included. The line cable and the usb c charging cable are also included. Quality feels nice. I didn’t use the line in cable which I believe is for when you go on a plane or connect to something that doesn’t have Bluetooth. The plastic that covers the outer part look very “cheesy” but its purpose is to keep the headset from scratching while in transport. Fit and feel is not as nice as let’s say a Bose 700. Can’t adjust the headphone width on the “fly”. I would need to remove the headset off and guess what size I need, adjust the size and put them back on. The around ear foam is somewhat stiff and hard. The ears get noticeably warm after extended usage. The battery life is ok. I get maybe 8-9 hours on a full charge. The noise cancelling works but definitely not as robust as let’s say the Bose 700. The headset connected to both to a Roku, windows 11 PC and Samsung cell phone via Bluetooth without any major issues. I would have to attempt a couple of times to pair the headset with the devices. For the price it’s not a bad unit at all. If I wanted a pair of headsets that I wanted a teenager to use and not worry about them losing or breaking a $300 pair of headsets this would be it. The company was kind enough to ship this unit out to me for free to test.

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 18, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Expectations exceeded!?
author: Juice
content: The Build: These headphones appear to be well built. The headband adjusts with a clicks that feel solid and unforced. They have a sleek and clean look.Comfortability: the TOZO headphones are slightly larger and heavier than my previous headphones. However, the fit is alot better and the larger earpads make for a vastly superior feel. I have a smaller head, and the headphones fit snuggly, which I like. My son has a larger head, and they also for him comfortably.Sound quality: I am not an audiophile by any stretch, but I do enjoy good sound when I'm listening to my music. These headphones do not sound at all tinny, the bass is warm and solid and the highs are crystal clear. The sound is considerably better then my previous headphones.Microphone: The headphones have a built-in microphone that is adequate for communication, but not for professional recording. Audio from the mic sounds a bit like you're in a tunnel, but I really never expect much from aheadphone mic.Noise Canceling / App: I was completely surprised when I discovered the TOZO app and linked them up to the phones. The app provides six noise-canceling modes that work beautifully. I use these to listen to audio books when my kids are watching TV or gaming, the nose cancellation makes it an enjoyable experience for all of us while spending time together in the same room. Change the mode and ambient sound is mixed in with my content, maybe it great for times when I'm walking the dogs and want to hear the traffic. Further, once the device is added to the app, you can change modes even when the phones are paired to a different device.Other notes: I have not used the headphones long enough to drain the battery yet, so I have no real data on how long a single charge lasts. So far I have listened for over 6 hours, and had more than 45% charge left.Delay: Sometimes with Bluetooth devices you notice a delay, it can be really noticeable when you are watching a movie and the person's lips don't align with the sound. I am thrilled to say that their is absolutely no latency with these headphones.Overall these headphones exceeded my expectations! That being said, I do not know how they line up to the competition in quality, but I can't imagine better performance at this price.Oh, I almost forgot to mention that I love having them in pink! Hopefully Tozo will add purple to the available colors of future headphones.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars I can do housework with these on!
author: naturalmama
content: I'm fairly new to Bluetooth earbuds and have been using a cheap version for a couple of years to listen to audiobooks when I'm doing things around the house. These had good reviews, and I liked the blue color, so I ordered a pair and have been using them for the last couple of weeks.Long story short, they are fantastic. I can run the garbage disposal with these things on and barely hear it. I can vacuum while listening to a book and not miss anything. I can just put them on so that my kids think I'm listening to something, and it makes their voices much quieter. :) I'm not exactly sure how long the battery life is, but I've only charged them once, and I use them almost every day, sometimes for hours at a time. The buttons are pretty easy to figure out, but a couple of them are oddly placed (for me), so that I hit them when I don't mean to or hit the wrong one. I'm always accidentally turning off the noise cancelling because the button is located right where I grab the headphones to adjust them or put them on. Overall, though, these are great, and as long as they hold up, I'm really happy I decided to spend a little money on them even though I already have earbuds.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars OneOdio A71 Hi-Rez Studio Recording Headphones Review
author: PittTronics
content: The OneOdio A71 Hi-Res Studio Recording Headphones are an impressive option for those seeking high-quality audio performance without breaking the bank. These headphones offer a well-rounded combination of comfort, sound quality, and versatility.The A71 headphones feature 50mm neodymium drivers that deliver a clear and balanced sound profile. The Hi-Res audio support ensures that you can enjoy your music with exceptional detail and accuracy. Whether you're listening to music, watching movies, or working on audio recordings, these headphones provide a rich audio experience.Comfort is key during extended listening sessions, and the A71 doesn't disappoint. The adjustable headband and cushioned ear cups offer a snug fit that doesn't sacrifice comfort. The headphones' foldable design makes them portable and convenient for on-the-go use.OneOdio has also taken versatility into account. The A71 comes with two detachable cables – one coiled and one straight – which is particularly handy for studio recording setups or casual listening. The headphones' closed-back design helps isolate sound, enhancing the immersive experience.While the audio quality is generally excellent, some audiophiles might notice a slight emphasis on bass. Additionally, the build quality, while decent, might not match the premium feel of higher-end headphones. However, given the price point, the build is more than satisfactory.In conclusion, the OneOdio A71 Hi-Res Studio Recording Headphones provide an impressive balance of audio quality, comfort, and versatility. Whether you're a music enthusiast, a content creator, or just someone who values good sound, these headphones offer a compelling option at an affordable price.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars OK, except 3.5mm jack to headphones is proprietary, cable doesn’t stretch much.
author: Rob D.
content: I bought a 3.5mm male/female 10ft extension cable as the headphone cable wouldn’t reach from my stereo to my recliner as it doesn’t really stretch very well. Well, the 3.5mm headphone jack that goes into the headphones has a square nub on it and a regular 3.5mm jack will not fit into the headphones. So I took a chance and drilled out the 3.5mm proprietary port on the headphones so it will accept a regular round 3.5mm, and dummy luck was on my side, it worked. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Hell Yeah
author: Rick Stepien
content: I needed a new pair of cans and was looking at wood ones b/c I thought they looked great. The dark brown coloring meets the look I was going for. It came with two cords and a carrying bag. The sound is extremely crisp. The bass tones are full sounding and I haven't noticed any distortion or cracking when both heavy bass and higher tones are playing at the same time. I tested volume a bit - what I found was they out performed my volume tolerance, playing just as clean and crisp at high and low volumes.Noise cancellation wise the covering on the ear pads do provide some along with the closed back of the speakers. I didn't buy them specifically for NC - so not a big issue. If you need that feature - there might be better options.The headphones themselves feel appropriate weight, not too light or heavy. The speaker portions feel solid and the cups themselves articulate in, out, and rotate to better fit your shaped head. I wear a 7 1/4" hat and have to have both extended fully out. This does flex the upper strap quite a bit. The upper strap on my old headset failed (it was made of plastic mostly). This headset has a fabric similar to the speakers with I believe a metal strap of some sort inside for the upper strap. I am hopeful it will last longer.The two cords, one was significantly shorter than the other and features a push button control of some sort. It has standard headphone connections on both ends I believe 3.5mm. The other cord (the one I am using) is brown, much longer, and has a coil in it. I was apprehensive but it works really well. That cord has a standard connector on one side and the larger 6.35mm that you can plug into one side of the headphones. It also has a 3.5mm jack on the other side if you use a different cable.Overall great headset for use at my desk. Great headset if you have an portable audio player with a jack.

title: 2.0 out of 5 stars Expensive gaming headset going bad? Replace with this! (Updated)
author: Squidslinger
content: Not completely replace, depends on the headset you have before and your mic needs. Many gaming headsets have USB sound cards in a small attachment in the cord. I'm speaking from experience with a HyperX Cloud II. Frankly, I love the Cloud II for a lot of reasons. Most important being it's an extremely sturdy design which holds up better than others.When you've had a set disintegrate on your head because of cheap plastic breaking down, you learn what to look for in a proper set. However, the Cloud II suffers the same problem that every wired headset or headphone suffers with time. Damage to the tiny wires inside the cable. When this happens, you are kinda stuck with either buying a whole new set or learning how to solder and repair the set yourself.This is all what happened leading up to my purchase of these OneOdio headphones. Now I do have solder experience but, the right equipment needed to work on the Cloud IIs, I didn't have. When calculating the cost of what I'd need, I estimated potentially maybe $30 worth of tools. Not the "$2" quotes a lot of guides online tell you (because they don't need to buy all the equipment). There was also the problem of recognizing where the break in the cable was. Often times these happen near the jack which is easy to fix. However, in my Cloud II, it happened up in the headset itself. Which means a bit more time and work trying to fix.Ultimately opting to get the OneOdios came down to a sale. They were on a sale that put them down into the price range of how much I'd need to fix the Cloud IIs. Given I've got smaller headphones that work just fine from the Cloud II sound card, even deliver the same virtual 7.1 sound, meant to me that the OneOdios would work fine.Now I know, these don't have as good of a Mic as the Cloud II has so why would I give up on the Cloud II? Simple, I had bought a Blue Yeti for my mic usage as I got fed up with how poor much of the headset mics were. I never used my Cloud II's other than testing. So there I had no value on using the Cloud II's. Mic problem had been long solved.Next it came down to the quality of the sound. Would the OneOdio's be just as good? Cloud IIs have 50mm drivers. The OneOdio have 40mm. Smaller but, when I compare the sound quality, they are virtually identical. Really could not tell the difference.So the next major factor which helped decide my OneOdio purchase was the cable setup. These have plugs on the headset and for the audio device. Meaning, if the cable gets a break in it, just swap the cable out, no need to toss the set. If Hyper X or other game headset makers did this, it would be a game changer and would solve another major issue with the sets breaking. However, they make over $100 in some cases on each set and people are often more than willing to buy a new one vs fix or replace. Hyper X won't sell just refurb or renewed headsets because then people would likely realize they could get cheap headsets by just buying the parts individually. So it's a long shot to expect headset makers to do this kind of feature except on expensive sets.Now, where OneOdio loses some points. Simply, the frame is a recipe for breaking. It's plastic. Granted it doesn't feel like cheap plastic but, it's still a weak point. Especially the swivel feature.OneOdio also has the same love of the crappy fake leather that it seems everyone uses. They use it on the head area and on the ear cushions. This stuff is utter crap. I've used it on numerous sets that came with it over the years. It falls apart very quickly. My Cloud II had it and the head cushion strip is almost all exposed and the earpads that had it disintegrated within a few months of use.Then lastly, this is kinda silly but for some reason OneOdio doesn't put a R or L to tell you which channel is which on the headphones, except underneath the clips where you can change out the ear cushions. Come on, there are about 3 or 4 places I can think to put these indicators on the external that wouldn't make the product look bad but for some reason OneOdio puts them in the one place you'll never see. Pretty silly.Ultimately, this is a great headphone. It solves my replacement issue and makes me realize I can get by quite a long time without buying expensive headsets. Some quirks but, for the cost of it, could be worse. There are sets that run over $150 that have more issues than these headphones do. Definitely would buy again if needed.*Update*Well they lasted 6 months before the plastic that allows the headphones to twist and turn decided to break. It's just a simple connection inside the unit. Definitely the weak point. Guess I'm gonna break out the soldering iron and try to patch the innards into the Cloud II after all. Great headphone till now. Lost a star due to poor materials for the definite stress point of the headphone.*UpdateNo response from OneOdio after a week of warranty submission approval. Extended warranty was accepted. OneOdio has not responded. Losing more stars.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Comfy and clear
author: Dominique Cyprès
content: The headphones look snazzy, feel nice on my head, and sounds great. I think they're my favorite of any headphones I've ever had. I tend to use them mostly as wired headphones but they work pretty well on Bluetooth as well. My only complaint about the Bluetooth functionality is the controls for seeking forward or backward. Like many Bluetooth headsets, three rely on the volume +/- buttons, but where others headsets use a double-click of these buttons to perform seeks, these require the user to hold one of the volume buttons for what feels like kind of a long time before it seeks, and then it only seeks by one increment until the button is pressed and held again. The headphones shipped with a silky drawstring bag to hold them and two audio cables: a sturdy 6.35mm to 3.5mm cable, TRS on both ends, with a coiled section like an old telephone cable; and a thinner 3.5mm TRS to 3.5mm TRRS cable with a built-in microphone. That first cable works really well and I use it all the time. The 3.5mm end of it has these little metal protrusions at the bar of the sleeve that slot into the 3.5mm port on the headphones; your have to take care to make sure this is fully inserted if you're using the cable to listen to a 6.35mm source, but the sound is clear and the jack stays securely inserted. The other cable, the one with the in-line mic, is a totally different story. The one I got simply doesn't work. I haven't really tested the mic, but the cable simply doesn't get a proper signal into the headphones. I can turn any device up to full volume and all I'll be able to hear through that cable is a barely detectable whisper. I tried my own 3.5mm TRS to 3.5mm TRS cable of another brand in the same configuration and it worked just fine, so I think that cable with the in-line mic really just doesn't work. I've seen similar complaints on the listing for this same cable sold separately by the manufacturer. I wasn't planning to use the mic anyway, though, so I'm not really bothered.All in all, there are a couple little annoyances but most of the time they're a non-issue for me and the headphones are a joy to use.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good Bang for the Buck
author: Team Bearcat
content: I have a big skull. My wife gives me crap about it regularly, but the joke is on her, she married me, I digress....These fit my cranium, but only on the largest possible adjustment, but they do fit, and comfortably.The biggest "want" that I had for these, was for them to fit over my ear, and what I mean is not that the muffs rest on my ears, but surround my ears. My ears fit within them perfectly. Checked a very important box for me.Another big "want" was to be wired with a 1/4" plug to go into the stereo receiver near my desk to listen to my vinyl collection without driving my family nuts that the old man is blasting old Led Zeppelin albums again... I knew that it came with that plug, but didn't know that two cables were included, and that they're interchangable. You can swap cables on the fly. The cable with the 1/4" jack is long, and has a coiled portion to stretch out to like 9' if needed. I currently have it going about 3 feet away, and there is plenty of slack. The headphones have both the 1/4" and standard headphone jack on them, one on each side. The flexibility to use different cables for my different devices was huge to me. This helped me push my rating to 5*Although noise cancelling was advertised, it wasn't that important to me as I would be using these in my home office to listen to vinyl, video games, streaming video, etc... while working or when my kids are sleeping, so I don't really need to block anything out. With that said, there is no active noise cancelling of any kind, and at this price, you shouldn't expect it. The only noise cancelling you get is from the seal that the headphones make around the ear combined with whatever noise is pumping through these, that's it. For most people that would be fine, and in my case it works perfectly. My issue is that when you advertise it and use it as a selling point, you need to be absolutely clear how your product achieves that selling point.For what I listen to, these work out great. They're not going to blow your mind, but they get the job done, and they do it pretty well. I would say that if you're looking for a good set of headphones for casual use, these are good. However if you're like me and want the flexibility to use these with your old school stereo, while being able to use them with your other devices, these are tremendous value.For good sound performance and having the flexibility features that I wanted at this price point, I had to give them 5*.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Works as expected and better!

I listen to mainly heavy metal and I also like some EDM of different varieties. They sounded great, as expected. So I had to see if they met other expectations. I got a guitar amplifier out, a small Yamaha practice amp. I also got out my Schecter Damien 8 Platinum with 808Xs. And I played the nastiest riffs into that Yamaha. These little headphones were loud and overwhelming, while being clear and precise to the tone. You couldn't tell a difference between the raw tone coming out of the speaker, and the sound coming from the headphones. The only difference was your atmospheric noise pollution was cancelled out. It's kinda like a personal sound room or studio experienced. These headphones are worth it. If you jam, give these a try.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect at home, everyday listeners.

content: I love the weight, they feel well made. The band feels sturdy, and the muffs don't feel like they'll snap or pop out of their joints. They sound great, they don't squeeze your temple into having a migraine, the cord is long enough for you to move around in your chair and not worry about yanking them out or pulling something in a twitch of motion ( ie: you can headbang, dance, whatever you want, eat in your chair, and you won't pull them or your computer out and onto the floor). As with most {removable} cables, though, you'll find that rubbing the cable at all makes an enhanced noise (say your arm hits it and rubs it, it amplifies the rubbing sound in your ear). Also, this particular set's cable is a special-fit end, meaning if for whatever reason you lost this cable, I don't know if any ole generic cable would fit in its plug, since the plug has a different shaped edge (it's not round, more like a keyhole shaped edge), but, yeah. they're great. title: 5.0 out of 5 stars OneOdio A71 sound & comfort is most definitely worth the price for your ears
author: SmartShopper
content: Ok lets start with I'm not a person who feels investing in overly priced or very expensive headsets is worth my wallet ever again. What I needed and wanted were very solid listening headphones for Music, Movies, Streaming & Gaming. So doing a long lasting research for a few weeks I went with OneOdio wired Red/Black A71.I was not disappointed, The packaging was very welcoming, the use of separate detachable dual 6.35/3.55mm red coiled plug and a dual 3.5mm plug I use for my PS4Pro Controller is a trend setter. The cups and fit is very very comfortable fit.Sound: With 40mm Drivers offer a very solid bass and a very clean balanced sound across all the uses I mentioned above. No tin can type of reverb that I noticed.Build: Well it is $33 bucks, so I did not expect it feel like it was made from pieces of the Berlin wall. It feels just as solid as Sony PS4 Gold wireless but with much greater mobility then add the pillow soft cups and a well padded overhead. I do feel any misuse or mishandling will not be in your favor. Durability wise I don't know yet, as I only had these for a few days. But I'm not a mad man. I like to treat my stuff w/ care and that alone usually works with longevity of my gadgets.Surprises: The 3.55 Mic sound was actually surprisingly good on my ps4pro. I was able to hear others and others were able to hear me. I do wish a Mute toggle was available tho without continue use of just holding it. The daisy chain linking sounds like a future plan for when it may be needed. The matching carrying bag is dope.In Closing: I highly recommend these if you're not trying to break the bank. Personally Headphones are for a enjoyable convenience. But if you truly enjoy true audio sound then may I suggest to investing into a Sound Speakers or a Home Theater for your home. As for OneOdio I look to see what other products you have to offer.Side note purchase: I also paired these up with "Envil" 3.5mm USB-A converter (In red to match the wire lol) I the same day for my PC / PS4 and the "OneOdio" sound sent into my ears did not disappoint.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States September 15, 2020

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Great headphones, meh cables.
author: Coyote
content: Sound quality is great for the price point, if the mix is good. Crappy mixes mastered for tiny laptop and cellphone speakers will sound muddy without EQ'ing the bass down, but that's an issue with the mastering, not the headphones. Otherwise, the sound is good. Punchy bass, crisp highs and mids. Everything I was looking for and expect, even at a higher price point. Durability remains to be seen, but the headphones are holding up well so far.The biggest shortfall of these headphones is the same as just about every other set of headphones on the market... Fragile cables. Nobody puts enough strain relief on their cables and if you move around at all while wearing these, your cable will start to break almost instantly, leading to one or both channels dropping out and crackling randomly. Don't plan on using these while you're moving around unless you want to buy a new cable. Also, don't use these for your phone unless you're going to leave it on the table or carry it in your hand all the time. Putting it in your pocket or even a holster will put way too much strain on the cheap jacks. One bump, pull or a little bit of strain and the wires start to go. A 90 degree plug would help, but *nobody* uses them.These cables specifically seem to use the cheapest plugs available. Relatively thick insulation on the wires, but I suspect that's all for show and the actual wires themselves are the same hair-thin, ultra fragile crap that everybody else uses. Started having issues with the short cable after only about 2 weeks of wearing them around the house. The longer cable got me three uses before they started crackling and dropping out. Furthermore, it doesn't look like I can replace the 1/8th inch cable with a standard patch cable because that one is deep set with a flat spot.Final opinion: Buy them for the sound quality, but be prepared to purchase new cables. The 1/4" side (on the left driver) is generic so you'll need to buy a 1/4" to whichever size you need.Note: Before anyone says to just go wireless, I have a hard enough time just keeping my phone and laptop charged up when I'm on the go, I really don't need another thing to plug in every couple of hours.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not super sexy but has a great personality.
author: P. Lucas
content: Good flat sound signature, not the most comfortable if you have a big head.I bought the Pro-30 version of these (same design except round puffy ear cushions) and read that some people like these better. I liked the idea of a bigger oval earphone so gave them a shot. Long story short I'll probably send these back. They aren't bad by any means, I just like the Pro-30s a little better.Comfort - these are by no means uncomfortable but they are not the "make you ooh and ahh" pillowy luxury of the Pro-30. The taller oval earpads didn't equal better comfiness for me. The clamp feels stronger too but that may ease with time.Sound - the sound is balanced and clear. There's plenty of gorgeous bass but not overwhelming, the midrange is smooth and right up front. The treble is crisp and not hissy or harsh. I would describe the sound curve as flat; very "true" to the original recording. If you're looking for smooth, balanced, pleasing tone that you could relax for hours listening to these will be great. You could happily fall asleep listening to these. The flip side is that these are not super dynamic by today's standards. To contrast the Pro-30s have bass that punches you in the face and treble that slaps you across the cheek. They are exciting and powerful but can get tiresome over long stretches. These are smooth as silk sound-wise. Not "crazy fun" but really nice.Features - love the no-adapter cable. Genius. These also have "R" and "L" imprinting on the inside of the driver dust cover- a small but super handy detail. I haven't tried the mic cord and probably won't. I don't like talking on the phone, especially through a headset. They fold up a little smaller than full size and come with a bag, probably won't use that either.Durability - these are cheaper heaphones. All plastic so I don't expect them to outlive me. They'll probably be just fine for several years of they're not abused. If you give them to a child they will probably destroy them after a while.If these had the comfort of the Pro-30s I would choose these. Since they don't I'll just turn down my bass and treble a little and use the Pro-30s. I paid less than $30 for these on sale so I might keep these for backup or a gift.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Price Matches Quality, Can't Go Wrong with Them.
author: Chris...
content: Let's start with the negatives because there are so few of them, and they are minor. First, the wire that comes with them could a tad bit longer. Second, I'm noticing in the coils in the coiled part of the wire like to flip at the ends so you get that 'U" shape that always appears on long phone cords (for those of you old enough to remember that). Finally, at the end of the day, if I am wearing these constantly for several hours, my ear can be a little tender. However, a slight adjustment to make sure the pressure point is off the ear fixes that. Perhaps an oversight they might fix with a future version is to make the input jack on the phones the same size on both ears. This way, if you're cord is coming from the left, you don't have to reverse the headphones. But again, all these things are minor.As for the positives, let's start with sound quality. At low and mid-level volume, there's very little difference between these and the vastly more expensive Sennheiser PXC 550 headphones I own and love. At louder volumes, there's a bit of a buzz, but we're talking volumes loud enough that it'd cause hearing damage if normally used at that level. For everyday normal use, the sound is fantastic.Physically, although plastic, the headphones still feel solid with a bit of heft to them, but aren't weighty. Perhaps one of the more fascinating idea is that you add a second pair of phones via an included wire so two people can listen to music or watch something (although I have not tried it). Even though I mentioned the ear soreness above after a full day, the overall feel of the headphones is very comfortable. There's good tension on the phones so they don't fall off my head easily, but the pressure against the ear is negligible as well. The material on ear cushions and the band holding the two parts together is soft to the touch and feels well crafted (but time will tell).All said and done, I spent $40 (including tax) for these headphones. Right now, I see they're selling for around $34 before tax, which is a very fair price.

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Someone at OneOdio is not listening to these headphones.
author: Ray
content: Hi, Well, this time I really am not to sure how to start this review. The headband is generally the same one used on the $35 2canz, except on these phones the fasteners are smaller to fit the smaller cavity of the phones. Yeah, they are comfortable. They have that little extra padding inside the ear cup to make it more comfortable for the ear to sit in.The company Moukey who makes headphones stated that there isn't any real difference between a 40mm and 50mm driver. I think I'll take their word on that. So here's my experience.I bought one pair, and for the first time in my headphone listening life found that both drivers sounded different. In this case, the left side sounded better in that the bass response was still there, but the mids and hights were not so much sucked out. It was a more balanced sound. On the other hand, the right side was unfortunately, the typical "V-shaped" frequency response. A lot of flabby bass, sucked out mids and lots of highend.I then contacted Amazon, and they promptly sent me out a replacement pair. Unfortunately, these too suffered the same results. This time, not so bad, but the right side was better and the left side had the midrange pulled back. If only they at OneOdio would listen to these phones, maybe the driver quality would improve. I tried them on different devices, with both pairs being the same results I have told you about.One slight criticism of this model is the fact you can't just use your own 3.5 mil cord. You have to use there cord on the right side. That protrusion on the bottom of the right side would have to be modified so you could use your own cord. So that's it for me and OneOdio. These in no way are anywhere close to "studio." I'd stay away from these phones. If OneOdio wishes to contact me to see what could be done to remedy these issues, I am open.I have returned them back to Amazon.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 7, 2022

title: 3.0 out of 5 stars Great product. Poor durability.
author: CaveatEmptor
content: As my hearing deteriorated I began having trouble following dialog on TV. In November 2020 I bought a soundbar and the Avantree Ensemble headphones to see if either would help. The soundbar helped a little but the Avantree headphones were fantastic! I gave away the sound bar and used the Avantree headphones every day after that. The sound quality is great, there is no lag between between the TV audio and the headphones, you can turn the TV sound off and use only the headphones so no-one else is disturbed, the over-the-ear earpads are comfortable and, as a bonus, they block most ambient noise making the TV audio even clearer, headphone volume adjusts easily without taking them off.After a few months the headband snapped. The headband (the part that goes over your head) is a thin plastic strip and clearly not durable. The constant, but gentle, flexing putting the headphones on and off weakens the band until it snaps. Other reviewers have reported the same problem. This is a design flaw and it needs to be fixed; my other headphones, some much older, do not have this problem, so it is definitely fixable. I repaired the snapped headband by gluing a flexible plastic splint over the broken band, and then taping it all together for added strength. This worked OK but the headphones ended up a little looser than before.In June 2023 the headphones would no longer charge when placed in the charging base. It was as if the headphones and charging base were no longer making good electrical contact. I could have charged the headphones using a cable, but that is a lot less convenient than just placing them in the base after use.I loved the product and its original convenience so much, I bought the same product again to replace my now faulty ensemble. The new headphones are great, as before, but I worry about the headband snapping again, and the charging base eventually not working. The last set lasted only 2 years and 7 months, much of that with a broken & repaired headband. For a product that costs almost $100 after tax, that is a disappointing lifespan.Bottom line: the Avantree Ensemble is a fantastically effective convenient product that improved my life enormously. But it's not durable, has a limited lifespan, and replacing them every so often is an expensive proposition.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States June 27, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Avantree has incredibly good customer support

Rie from their customer support was in contact with me every step of the way. She was able to answer all of my question and promptly at that. At each and every step of the way, there was Rie sending me information about the status of my return with detailed information to help along the way.Rie was always in direct communication with me and I felt that her experience shined, it was this person in their customer support which really impressed me with this company. To keep things simple, she was the only person that I was in contact at each step of the way.I will certainly come back in the future for my audio headset needs in the future.Lastly, I would like to let people know about their on/off switch on the Avantree Ensemble (Headsets). With this unit you just flip a switch (on or off), gone is the step of holding down a power button waiting for your headset unit to connect with the base and then the same thing in order to power off your headset. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Pleasantly surprised with the quality!
author: SaltedFish
content: On the whole I have been really happy with these. I was worried since they weren't active noise cancelling like my last headphones, there'd be a lot of ambient noise. Turns out it's very easy to tune that out. The overall sound quality is such that I often find myself becoming very engrossed in whatever I am listening to, in a way that's sort of new to me. Which is to say, I am very pleased with the listening experience from these headphones. Everyone is of course different when it comes to sound, but to sum it up: I am not disappointed in the least by the lack of ANC or the sound quality.The only thing I'm kinda disappointed in is the docking station. For whatever reason, it's possible to put the headset in the station and not have it make contact with the charging contacts. I find myself constantly having to jimmy it around until it finally seats properly. About 3/5 times I place the headphones in the docking station and walk away, only to hear a faint, "Welcome to Avantree!" and have to go back to jostle it until it makes contact. I think what's happening is when I put the headphones in the station, they make contact just long enough to make the headphones think it's about to charge (which causes them to enter charging mode), but then the weight of the headphones causes them to rock backwards and out of contact, which makes the headphones think they've been picked up and are about to be used. It's a little annoying, and frankly if I had known this before I had gotten them, I may have gone with another product.That said, I'll be hanging onto these now that I have them. The range (significantly longer than my other bluetooth headphones) and weight (possible to comfortably wear these for hours) are excellent as well, and the charging thing isn't enough of a deal breaker to make me send them back.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States November 19, 2023

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Charging issues
author: Sspear
content: First of all, these have been a marriage saver! My husband likes to watch tv before bed and I want quiet. He says they’re very comfortable. Also worth noting, he has severe tinnitus and some hearing loss and can hear clearly. title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Perfect Gift for My Grandmother - A Game Changer!
author: Laurashome
content: This was a recent purchase for my grandmother, and it turned out to be perfect for her daily use. The headphones have significantly improved her daily routine, allowing her to enjoy her favorite music, and TV shows in comfort.First off, the setup process was incredibly straightforward. My grandmother, who is not particularly tech-savvy, was able to connect the headphones to her devices without any hassle. The simplicity of the design and user interface made it a breeze for her to understand and use them right out of the box.Comfort is another aspect where these headphones truly shine. They are lightweight and have soft, cushioned ear pads that fit perfectly. She can wear them for hours without feeling any discomfort.The sound quality is outstanding. It delivers clear, rich sound that enhances her listening experience, whether she's enjoying classical music or the latest mystery novel. The noise-canceling feature is a bonus, helping her stay immersed in her audio without being disturbed by the background noise.Battery life is impressive as well. She doesn't have to worry about charging them frequently, which is a huge plus for both of us. The headphones easily last through several days of moderate to heavy use, making them very reliable.Overall, these headphones have been a game changer. title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Enhances Voice Clarity
author: Cck
content: Just received these and so far: easy to connect to our older Samsung TV, easy-to-follow instruction book, all needed connections included in box, tv speaker sound can still be on while using headphones. For me the biggest plus - they really enhance voice clarity when watching a movie with "too loud" background music. Now I can hear what actors are saying. Negatives - not the best sound quality when listening to music. Lose out on the depth, layers of sound. Also the difference between the lowest volume level on headset and next step up is way too big! I have really good hearing. Need much more gradual volume increases. Don't know if this will be a deal breaker. My old JVC headset was great in this regard ( could move sound volume up in really small, gradual increments). Almost seems like these headphones are made for those with some hearing loss. Range seems good - can walk around house and still hear. Don't yet know how comfortable headset will be after wearing for any extended period. Fortunately Amazon has an extended holiday return policy. Will get to try for a couple months.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Literally mind-blowing upgrading from AirPods Pro 2
author: Christian Waymire
content: Beats**all coming from an airpods & airpods pro 2 user**Two notes about me:* I have a pretty average sized head & ears* I wear glassesThoughts:- Noise isolation is way better than people give credit for, works about as well as the active noise cancellation on my airpods pro 2.- I can FEEL the bass.- Can hear all kinds of details in music (like when I upgraded to airpods pro but slightly better than even those). The AirPods gen 2 did that for me, then the AirPods Pro 2 did it again, and now these are doing the same.- Electronic music sounds absolutely amazing. Better than any other headphones or speaker I’ve heard.- Classical sounds amazing—way better than AirPods Pro 2.- Folk sounds amazing, & it’s like someone’s playing a really high end guitar right next to me while also serenading me.- Piano also sounds especially amazing- Case is slightly padded, but leaves a lot to be desired there—they also barely fit (see pictures).- They feel durable, even at hinges (which shocked me).- They DO fingerprint easily, if that matters to you.- Box is very sleek & giftable.- Not having the automatic ear detection is really nice for when I lift one side up to hear someone or something.- They are more comfortable than AirPods Pro, even with memory foam ear tips on those. But they do get slightly annoying with glasses but there is a sweet spot where it’s not bad (if I angle the headband towards the back of my head instead of having it straight up and down). But it’s not so uncomfortable that I don’t want to use them. Merely a minor inconvenience.- I ever so slightly wish I could see the battery percentage on my phone while charging, but it’s not any real inconvenience.- The micro-USB charger is potentially going to be a slight inconvenience because they wear out—USB-C or a lightening cord would’ve been way better.- Pairing with an iPhone is extremely easy.- The included carabiner for the case is a nice afterthought, but it’s a super flimsy carabiner and the loop keeping it on the case is tiny and I wouldn’t trust it. If it were better sewn and had a bigger loop, that’d be fantastic. I CAN attach an aluminum locking carabiner, but it’s just barely big enough for that.- Charging seems pretty fast, and while I do wish it would show me the percentage while charging, I really appreciate seeing the percentage in the battery widget while connected because other non-apple Bluetooth headphones don’t have that and I’m left guessing how much is left on the tiny control center icon with those.In sum, I HIGHLY recommend these if you’re looking for good bluetooth headphones and don’t have $400+ to spend. I snagged them for $99.95, and I couldn’t be happier. They’re definitely a good value at $200, but they’re mind blowing at a part-time, minimum wage budget. Almost every feature has been either mind blowingly fantastic, but those that aren’t are barely worth commenting on.Are they perfect? No. Should one expect perfection at this price? Absolutely not. I’d highly recommend buying if they’re in your budget!!!
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States October 17, 2023

timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 18, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars These headphones deserve the hype!
author: Mariah Chapman
content: At last I finally found the perfect wireless headphones!! I bought these back in November when they were on sale for Black Friday (only $80!) and wanted to give them a test period before I reviewed them. Here’s what I’ve experienced this far:Pros1. The sound quality is impeccable. Literally everything is so clear and crisp. Funny enough, to put it into perspective, I was watching a movie and did not notice faint background music until I put these headphones on.2. The battery life is great. For me, they last roughly 72 hours before I need to fully recharge them. With charging, it takes maybe 40 minutes to an hour to get back up to a full charge. Impressive3. They’re compact and foldable. You’d be surprised how many headsets don’t fold when you’re done using them but these are perfect if you need to travel.4. They can connect to anything! I connected them to the Bluetooth on my tv for the first time since I didn’t want to wake my roommate up at 2am and set up was easy and simple.5. Changing the volume or song is simple and easy.6. Not really a pro, just an opinion, but they are really cute and stylish.Cons:1. A lot of people were right about them hurting your ears after having them on for too long; maybe more than 4 hours of continuous wear. I wish the part that goes around your ears was a little bigger to minimize the discomfort, but nonetheless it’s not a huge deal.2. Don’t connect them to numerous things at once. For instance, I had these paired with my iPhone and laptop at the same time. When I turned on my laptop it disconnected from my iPhone automatically and vice versa. My suggestion, disconnect from the device you’re not using and only focus on one sole device at a time.3. I wish the charger came with a charging block instead of just a wire. If you don’t have an extra block make sure you get one.4. They are not 100% noise cancelling but it does block out a good amount of outside noise5. My only concern is that when you call someone or someone calls you there’s a weird echo in the background. Like every time you talk it sounds like you’re talking in a tunnel? Again not a big deal just something I’ve noticed.Overall, I’m really happy with this purchase and if you’re considering getting these just do it. I really needed them for studying purposes and they get the job done 100%.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States January 19, 2024

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Immersive Sound and Stylish Design: A Review of Beats Solo3 Wireless On-Ear Headphones
author: CMReviewer
content: The Beats Solo3 Wireless On-Ear Headphones are a fantastic choice for anyone seeking high-quality sound and convenient wireless connectivity. From their sleek design to their impressive battery life, these headphones have quickly become a favorite accessory in my daily life.One of the standout features of the Beats Solo3 headphones is their immersive sound quality. Whether I'm listening to my favorite music, podcasts, or audiobooks, the audio is crisp, clear, and full-bodied, allowing me to fully immerse myself in the listening experience.The wireless connectivity is another major selling point for these headphones. Thanks to the Apple W1 headphone chip and Class 1 Bluetooth technology, pairing the headphones with my devices is seamless and hassle-free. Plus, with up to 40 hours of listening time on a single charge, I never have to worry about running out of battery during long commutes or flights.However, it's important to note that the ear covers on the Beats Solo3 headphones may not fully cover the ears, which can cause discomfort for those with sensitive ears. As someone who prefers over-ear headphones for this reason, I did notice some discomfort after extended periods of use.Overall, despite this minor issue, the Beats Solo3 Wireless On-Ear Headphones are an excellent choice for anyone in search of stylish, high-quality headphones with impressive sound and wireless convenience. Just be mindful of the ear cover size if you have sensitive ears.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States May 4, 2024

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Love these.
author: Bart
content: I got my first pair in 2016 for free from Apple when I bought a computer with my student discount. I used them every day until sometime in 2023 when the overhead band snapped. So I bought these to replace them.I have a very small head and stretched earlobes. Most over ear head phones are way too big and fall off if I look down. Or they sit in a way that makes my plugs dig into the pressure point behind the ear lobe. These head phones do neither. They fit snug without hurting my hears, these are on ear not over the ear. They do start to ache if I wear them for several hours with my glasses on though, like if I’m on a flight for a long time. But I think that happens with most headphones.They have great base and are great for noise cancelling. They fully charge in about on hour. Maybe less.Definitely recommend if you’ve got a small head and shuffle to find headphones that stay on. If you’re a giant man with a giant head, don’t get these. They’ll be too small.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Perfect for running, ear pads a bit small
author: M
content: I run outdoors frequently and was looking for a decent pair of headphones because my area is noisy and I was tired of constantly adjusting my airpods while running. I wanted something with serviceable audio quality that I also wouldn't mind putting through the constant wear and tear of sweaty runs. I was previously wearing a more expensive pair of headphones to run, and while I do prefer those for use at home or for noise-canceling, they were too heavy and hot for running and I was worried about damaging them. The beats solo3 are a better fit for this particular use case (for me).Pros:- the apple bluetooth chip is extremely useful, it makes it so much more convenient to switch between devices! Major QOL improvement over other headphones I own- lightweight and don't make my ears hot during exercise- stay put well even with a lot of movement (I've even worn these while hanging upside down at the gym and they didn't fall off)- blocks out the perfect amount of sound for outdoor running, such that I'm not distracted by ambient noise but I still have enough situational awareness to hear a car honking at me at close range- audio quality is better than any of my in-ear headphones, which is really all I needed in this case- battery life is great, I never find myself running out of battery even though I use these quite a bitCons:- My primary reason for deducting a star: I was expecting these to be over-ear, but they're actually more like on-ear; the ear pads are a bit tight and sometimes they start to hurt my ears after wearing them for longer periods of time, usually after ~45 minutes (I'd be especially cautious if you have any cartilage piercings)- It's a bit hard to use the control buttons sometimes- the double tap to skip is a little finicky, sometimes if I press too quickly in succession or not hard enough it doesn't register. The volume controls are so much smaller and so far to the top and bottom, respectively, that I sometimes accidentally hit the center pause button instead. Still convenient to have controls there, but they have room for improvement. I also find myself wishing that I could use the controls from either side instead of just the one, but that's not a big deal.- I worry that the band might be damaging my hair a bit, as it's a pretty grippy material. It's not pulling out any hair, but I do wish it had a bit more slip since the headphones feel tight enough to stay put regardless

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Unmatched Style and Performance
author: Eric W.
content: I recently purchased the Beats Solo3 Wireless On-Ear Headphones, and I must say, they have left a lasting impression on me. From their sleek design to impressive sound quality and long-lasting battery life, these headphones have become my constant companion for both daily commutes and intense workout sessions.First and foremost, the design of the Beats Solo3 headphones is striking. The sleek and streamlined appearance, combined with the iconic Beats logo, exudes a sense of modernity and style. The headphones come in a variety of attractive colors, allowing users to express their personality and preferences. The on-ear design is comfortable and snug, providing a secure fit that stays in place even during vigorous activities.The sound quality is undeniably excellent. The Beats Solo3 headphones deliver a powerful and bass-heavy sound signature that suits various music genres. The bass response is deep without overpowering the vocals and trebles, resulting in an immersive audio experience. Whether I'm listening to my favorite tracks, watching movies, or playing games, the headphones never fail to impress with their rich and dynamic sound.The wireless connectivity is a game-changer. Pairing the Beats Solo3 with my devices is effortless, thanks to the Apple W1 chip. The Bluetooth connection remains stable and reliable, allowing me to move around without any dropouts. Additionally, the on-ear controls are intuitive and easy to use, enabling me to adjust the volume, skip tracks, and answer calls with a simple tap.The battery life of the Beats Solo3 headphones is outstanding. With up to 40 hours of playback on a single charge, I rarely have to worry about running out of power during extended use. Moreover, the Fast Fuel feature is incredibly handy, providing three hours of playback after just a 5-minute charge, perfect for those last-minute situations.The headphones also feature a built-in microphone, which works well for making calls and using voice assistants like Siri. However, the microphone's performance in noisy environments could be improved, as it tends to pick up background noise.Comfort-wise, the on-ear design may not be suitable for everyone, especially during prolonged wear. Some users might experience slight discomfort or ear fatigue after extended use, but this can be alleviated by adjusting the fit and taking short breaks.While the Beats Solo3 Wireless On-Ear Headphones deliver impressive sound quality and wireless convenience, the premium price tag might be a deterrent for some budget-conscious consumers. However, the product's performance and brand reputation are likely to justify the investment for audiophiles and fans of the Beats brand.In conclusion, the Beats Solo3 Wireless On-Ear Headphones are a stylish and reliable choice for music enthusiasts seeking powerful sound and seamless wireless functionality. With a few minor improvements in comfort and microphone performance, these headphones could easily score a perfect rating. If you prioritize style, sound quality, and long-lasting battery life, the Beats Solo3 headphones won't disappoint.
timestamp: Reviewed in the United States July 24, 2023

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Best of 3 in comparison
author: Paul Ratzlaff
content: I bought these flash sale for $41 versus the list price of 59.99 and compared it to the Raycon every day headphones which listed for 99.99 and I got through Black Friday sale for 69.99 and found the Raycons Had a better feel. The Life Q 20s had to be played with full volume on the phone did not connect automatically to Bluetooth like the Raycon did and they were not water resistant like the Raycons were. The Raycons had a more in-depth base about it and I liked the way the Raycons Told you that it was connected to the Bluetooth when you first put them over your ears. I could feel the sound better with the Raycons. The soundcore, Life Q 20s did not connect automatically and just gave you a series of bleeps to let you know it was connected. So construction wise and convenience wise and sound wise I found the Raycons better. I then compared the Raycons to a pair of beats solo3 which listed for 199 and you can get them at Costco in black for $99 which is what I paid for them in an Amazon cyber Monday sale. The sound quality of the beats solo3 was by comparison Superior to even the Raycons. If you set your phone volume to high, you can still adjust the beats up or down without it affecting the volume on your phone, whereas both the Raycon and the soundcore when you increase or decrease the volume it would increase or decrease it on your phone . I returned this product and spent the little extra money for the beats solo3 and am happy. But if you’re looking for a good sound for under 50 bucks the soundcore life Q20 is very good. For a price between 50 and 100 the Raycon fit the category and was great, and if you’re not afraid to spend the extra bucks, the beats solo3 is the best.

title: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Cordless Headphones for and Productivity
author: Shopsmart
content: I recently purchased the Beats Cordless Headphones and I must say, they have exceeded my expectations in terms of convenience and functionality. It has truly enhanced my overall experience and improved my quality of life.One of the standout features of these headphones is their compact design, making them easy to carry around. Whether I'm traveling or on the go, I can simply put them in my bag or pocket without any hassle. This portability allows me to have my headphones with me at all times, ensuring that I never miss out on an opportunity to absorb valuable material.Setting up the connection with these headphones is a breeze. The seamless Bluetooth connectivity ensures that I can quickly and effortlessly pair them with my devices. I appreciate the simplicity and reliability of the connection, as it saves me time and eliminates the frustration often associated with complicated setups.What I truly love about these headphones is the privacy they provide. With their excellent noise-canceling feature, I can immerse myself in my studies or work without any distractions. This privacy enables me to absorb more material effectively, leading to increased productivity. Moreover, I can enjoy my favorite music or podcasts without disturbing those around me, allowing me to create a peaceful environment wherever I go.The benefits of using the Beats Cordless Headphones are numerous. Not only do they enhance my learning and work capabilities, but they also provide me with more quality time. With these headphones, I can utilize my time more efficiently and make the most out of every moment.In conclusion, I highly recommend the Beats Cordless Headphones to anyone seeking convenience, functionality, and an improved quality of life. Its compact design, effortless connectivity, and privacy features make it a perfect companion for individuals who value productivity and personal time. Invest in these headphones, and you'll experience a significant positive impact on your daily routine and overall satisfaction.

title: 4.0 out of 5 stars Great Headphones but some cons.
author: Amazon Customer
content: These beats are really great and the adjustable thing on the top really lets them fit nice on your head. And the sound quality is actually amazing. On top of that, beats and apple have some sort of connected/deal (idrk) and because of this, when you turn them on, they automatically pair directly to your iPhone (I have a 14) and don’t make you go thru any annoying pairing process every time. They also directly show the beats icon, connection, and battery life directly on your iPhone. You also get a free month trial of Apple music plus. My only issue is that the ear part that surrounds your ear is rather small, so this may be an issue, and it is for me. After a while, my ears kinda begin to feel annoyed or hurt because it is not encompassing my full ear, so I feel that either the price of them, they could maybe have made them a little bigger. And the travel case is also pretty small and tight. I am pretty sure beats has a more expensive and different option that does fully surround your ear but it’s pretty pricey. Overall these are great and easy to use headphones.
